title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
Welcome to the County Health Open-Source Project, a community-driven effort to preserve, update, and extend the County Health Rankings & Roadmaps data after the loss of program funding.
For the past fifteen years (2010-2025), County Health Rankings & Roadmaps (CHR&R) has drawn attention to why there are differences in health within and across communities. The program highlights policies and practices that can help everyone be as healthy as possible. CHR&R aims to grow a shared understanding of health, equity and the power of communities to improve health for all. This work is rooted in a long-term vision where all people and places have what they need to thrive.
Following funding loss, the mission of the County Health Open-Source Project is to:

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
Community
Thanks for checking out our community of researchers, analysts, and public health practitioners who want to keep county-level health data publicly accessible. To get involved, check out our Contribution Guidelines and explore the resources below:
Measure Calculations GitHub Repository: This repo contains raw data, inputs, and scripts to calculate CHR&R measures. You can use it to review our methods, reproduce results, propose improvements, or update measures as new raw data become available. We especially welcome contributions that recalculate and refresh measures to keep them current.
Show and Tell Forum: A place to share completed projects, dashboards, and analyses using county-level data
Discussion Forum: General Q&A and troubleshooting space. Ask questions about methods, data, or specific use-cases. Anyone is welcome to ask a question or provide an answer.

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
Tools
Open-source tools for accessing, calculating, and exploring county-level health measures. Most tools have public GitHub repositories where anyone is welcome to suggest improvements or report bugs.
County Snapshot App: Interactive app for viewing and downloading county-level data. Designed for quick lookup without requiring data or programming expertise. Report bugs or suggest improvements via its GitHub Issues page.
countyhealthR package: R package for programmatic access to archived CHR&R data (2010–2025). Supports reproducible workflows and automated access to CHR&R data. Contributions and issue reports are welcome in the package repository.
Life Expectancy Calculator (LINK COMING SOON): Microsoft Excel calculator for estimating county-level life expectancy. Useful for method transparency and scenario testing.
Do you have an idea for a new tool? Tell us more in the Discussion Forum!

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
Archives
In funding loss, not everything can be maintained. To check out fifteen years of CHR&R history, visit our archives:
Data Archives (Zenodo): Versioned releases of CHR&R datasets for each year (2010–2025), each with a DOI for citation and direct download. There are two primary Zenodo repositories: one contains human-readable Excel files, designed for quick inspection and use by non-technical users, and the other contains relational files with metadata, which are most useful for analysts. The relational files serve as the backbone of the countyhealthR package and the County Snapshot app.
Methods and Source Documentation Archives (LINK COMING SOON): Static archive of measure definitions, source descriptions, and calculation notes from past releases. Use this to understand how measures were historically calculated.
Publications and White Papers (LINK COMING SOON): Past technical reports and methods papers describing the CHR&R model, measures, and methods.
What Works for Health Archives (LINK COMING SOON): Curated, evidence-informed summaries of policies, programs, and strategies shown to improve health and equity, last updated in 2025.

title: County Health Open-Source Project
section: If you’d like to help, please check out the Contribution Guidelines or use the Discussion Forum to share the ways you’re using CHR&R data in your own work. Let’s keep this important public data alive together!
text: If you’d like to help, please check out the Contribution Guidelines or use the Discussion Forum to share the ways you’re using CHR&R data in your own work. Let’s keep this important public data alive together!

title: Contribution Guidelines
text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the County Health Open Source Project!

title: Contribution Guidelines
text:
Ways to Contribute

Measure calculations repository
The measure calculations repository is the core engine behind CHR&R data. Following funding loss, we especially welcome contributions that help extend calculations beyond 2025/2026.

You can:

Add publicly available raw data for years beyond 2025/2026
Update calculation scripts to accommodate new data
Flag broken data sources or links
Propose alternative publicly accessible data sources if original sources are no longer available
Improve reproducibility, performance, or documentation of workflows



Important context:
Contributions should prioritize transparency, traceability, and alignment with historical methods
If methods change due to data availability, clearly document the change and its implications
We ask that you aim to contribute a measure in its entirety – in other words, if possible, please provide raw data, any necessary inputs, a clearly documented script for completing calculations, and a finalized measure dataset for any measure that you undertake.


How to contribute:
Submissions are reviewed before acceptance. To submit a contribution to the repository:

Start by opening an Issue describing:

The measure of health
The data source
Years covered
Any deviations from prior methods

Fork the repository and create a feature branch
Run calculation scripts locally and validate outputs
Update documentation to reflect changes
Submit a pull request with a clear summary and notes




County Snapshot
Contributions to the County Snapshot focus on usability, accuracy, and clarity.
You can:

Report bugs (e.g., filters not working, incorrect values, display issues)
Suggest usability or accessibility improvements
Propose new comparisons, tools, or explanatory text
Flag inconsistencies between the app and published data or documentation


How to contribute:

Open an Issue on the County Snapshot repository

If reporting a bug, please include clear reproduction steps, screenshots if possible, and the browser/device used.
For feature requests, briefly describe the public health use case.





countyhealthR package
Contributions to countyhealthR focus on functionality, reliability, and analyst experience.
You can:

File bugs related to data access, function outputs, or errors
Suggest or implement new helper functions
Improve documentation, examples, or vignettes
Add tests or improve error messaging


How to contribute:

Open an Issue to report bugs or discuss proposed changes
For code contributions:

Fork the repository
Create a feature branch
Follow tidyverse-style conventions where possible
Include documentation updates and tests when relevant
Submit a pull request referencing the related issue





Archived Data & Documentation 
Archived materials are intended for reuse, extension, and storytelling. 
You can: 

Use archived data to study trends, policy impacts, or health inequities 
Combine archived CHR&R data with new data sources 
Develop teaching materials, dashboards, or advocacy tools 
Share how you are using the data to inform local or regional decision-making 


How to contribute: 

Participate in the community discussion forum 
Share projects, analyses, or visualizations in the Show & Tell section 
Include links and citations to our data where possible 




Community Norms 

Be respectful and constructive 
Assume good intent 
Document decisions and tradeoffs clearly 
Prioritize equity, transparency, and public health impact 

We are especially committed to building an open-source community that is useful with or without deep GitHub or data expertise. 
Thank you for contributing to the future of county-level health data.
